Maker of high quality nylon whips
Gerrit's Whip Factory

Gerrit's Whip Factory

Gerrit is a whipmaker based out of Southern California. He produces high quality bullwhips and snake whips made from 650 nylon paracord. All whips are hand made one at a time and most are custom ordered. He makes whips of all sizes but his most common are 5ft children’s bullwhips, as well as 6 and 8 foot bullwhips for adults.

Gerrit has been cracking a whip ever since he was 10 years old and received his first whip as a birthday present. This 10 plait cowhide bullwhip has served him well (except that one issue with the TSA) and is still in his collection. However a few years of neglect as a child left it in a state where its better suited living out its life retired and on a shelf. Thats when he turned to nylon bullwhips. While performing in a circus he was introduced to a paracord bullwhip a coworker had made, and was impressed in the quality. After some research he decided to attempt to make on himself. The results were… poor. At the very least it was functional, but not what one would call a quality product. More paracord was ordered and attempt number two began. This time lengths were adjusted, tightness was consistent, and the learning curve was beginning to flatten out. This would be a suitable whip for Gerrit’s needs, but he was hooked. His third whip needed to be better as he intended on giving it as a gift. By this point he had fallen down the rabbit hole of whipmaking, there was no turning back.

To this day Gerrit is still honing his skills and tweaking things. He experiments with new plaiting patterns, color combinations, and takes meticulous notes on almost every aspect of his whips so each one can be an improvement on the last. This is why every whip that leaves his workbench comes with a satisfaction guarantee. If you are ever dissatisfied with the quality of a whip you can return it for a full refund. It is also why any whipmakers or whip enthusiasts that want to offer feedback can feel free to contact him any time. Gerrit is always aiming to improve so he can create the highest quality product, otherwise he wouldn’t put his name on it.

A part by part breakdown of how we make our whips.

The foundation of our whips.

The braided interior of the whip.

Core

The foundation of our whips.

The core is a thin steal rod inserted into a slinker cord core. This core is shot loaded if requested and thatched to the rod using artificial sinew. The handle can be any length desired though 8-10 inches is standard with 12 inches being the rare exception. The core is then bolstered before being incased in the first belly.

Internal Bellies

Bellies aid in the structure and taper of your whip.

By default any whip over 5’ will have 2 internal bellies. These are plaited in traditional whipmaker’s plait in the handle and thong and with a tight 1x1 checkerboard pattern in the transition. This assists the bolstering and adds in a smooth transition of the whip. The internal the core and first belly may not match the color of your overlay, but the second belly will always be made out of the same color as one in your primary overlay. This insures that no color other than the ones you have requested will ever be seen from the outside of your whip. If you require a different method have no worries, we can accommodate your needs as best we can.

Overlay

The colorful exterior of your whip.

The final overlay is the only part of your whip that can be seen from the exterior. It’s the layer where we can have the most fun with color combinations. The final overlay is the only part of your whip that can be seen from the exterior. It’s the layer where we can have the most fun with color combinations. This is where your color choice, handle design, and thong pattern really shine and is the characteristic that make nylon whips truly unique. From vibrant colors, unique patterns, earth tones, black and white, or solid colors we can accommodate almost any need. If you have any questions, reach out to us. Chances are we’ll be able to come up with a custom design for you to meet your needs.

Since November of 2020 the thong is always braided in whipmaker’s plait in a method that avoids the dreaded “double strand”. For any whips before this date that are still in stock there may be a “double strand” where a strand has been dropped. This is very common in whips and is simply a characteristic of the standard plaiting method Gerrit learned originally. To the untrained eye it is hardly noticeable. If anyone does notice it, it is a great opportunity to bore all your friends with your knowledge in the construction of a whip. (Or is that just what Gerrit does?)

Fall and Fall-hitch

the final taper to your whip.

Whips are ended in a standard four point fall hitch that encompasses the fall. The final hitch is passed up under the other 3 and the fall ensuring the knot will hold tightly throughout the life of the whip. This creates the tightest possible ending to the thong allowing for the smoothest transition possible. This fine point aids in the cracking of the whip and is quite visually pleasing.

Do to the nature of tying this knot any whips sent in for repairs where the fall hitch has been removed, the knot untied, or other situation where the fall hitch has been altered, the whip may lose and inch or two of the overall length in order to retie. Of course this is avoided at all costs and we will notify you before this happens.

The falls themselves are a single strand spliced into itself. the internal strand half the length of the exterior sheath. This allows for a continued taper even in the fall itself ending your whip in a single nylon strand. It just can’t get any finer of a point than that. This is then attached above the fall hitch and then subsequently tied on with the fall hitch itself. The fall along with the cracker are the only two parts of a whip that will wear out over time. These can be replaced without untying the fall hitch completely and it is recommended that you never untie the fall hitch unless absolutely necessary. See the fall hitch replacement video by Nick Schrader in our recommended videos section or contact us for any further questions.

Crackers

The part that goes bang!

Crackers are made out of black kevlar thread that has been twisted together. They are all hand made, so lengths vary, but they aim to be 6” long unless otherwise requested. The kevlar thread is very resilient, and though it will wear out eventually, has a long life. This will provide thousands of cracks for hobbyist whip crackers and professionals alike. Though, like all crackers, their life will quickly diminish when used to cut through objects.

They are attached to the fall using a cow hitch that has been passed through the center of the fall using a micro lacing needle. These can be undone without any special equipment, however if you aim to replace the cracker and don’t have a lacing needle you will have difficulties. Contact us for recommended methods of replacing the cracker or view our recommended videos.

Heal and Transition Knots

Intricate and decorative knot-work.

These are the decorative foundation and endings on the handle of the whip.

The heal knot is what covers the base of your whip and adds a foundation to keep your hand from sliding off the handle. There are several knot combinations available to use here, each providing equal support. The choice between which knot you want is purely aesthetic.

The transition knot is an optional knot to add at the end of your handle. The goal of this knot is to hide the transition from the handle to the thong of your whip. This isn’t necessary in all cases though, as its has little physical importance to the structure of the whip. Gerrit himself goes back in forth on whether or not to add this knot depending on the braiding on the handle. That said, in any whip where the handle braiding doesn’t match the thong it is highly recommended to hide this transition. When the handle colors don’t match the colors of the thong the transition knot is necessary, there’s no way to make that transition pretty and we need to hide it.
